 The key differences, Matthew are the type of ammo used. Shotguns use cartridges containing buckshot or pellets (Jim, correct me if I'm wrong emoticon_xkill ), Whereas rifles use bullets. The classification used here are either sidearms or longarms.
jim's trucking

Sorry but I disagree there are only two types of gun type weapons. Hand guns which are held in one hand and everything else is a rifle.
I can imagine the Marine DS having trouble teaching you the difference between your weapon and your gun.
 
 For your edification, a rifle has a long barrel that has been scored (machined, engraved, scratched, etched, whatever you want to call it) on the inside so that the lines spiral toward the end of the barrel. The spirals inside the barrel are called rifling. This causes the projectile (bullet) to spin one way or the other and adds stability to the projectile as it flies toward the target. It keeps the bullet from tumbling through the air.
 
 A shotgun is a smooth bore gun and has no rifling inside the barrel. A shotgun is NOT a rifle. (Because it is a smooth bore firearm.)
 
 Modern cannons usually have rifling. Modern pistols have rifling but are not considered rifles. I don't know how long the barrel (or stock) has to be before a pistol becomes a rifle, but I have seen pistols with extremely long barrels...one that had been fitted with a shoulder stock and forestock (still had the pistol grip and the revolving chamber) so I suppose there's a point at which the name would change.
jim's trucking

The key differences, Matthew are the type of ammo used. Shotguns use cartridges containing buckshot or pellets (Jim, correct me if I'm wrong emoticon_xkill ), Whereas rifles use bullets. The classification used here are either sidearms or longarms.
You're not really wrong, but you're far from right!emoticon_wow 
 
 Shotguns can shoot slugs. In this case, the rifling is on the slug. Rifles are little bitty raised lines that spiral around the inside of a barrel (or in the case of shotguns, around the outside of the slug).
 
 Pistols (sidearms) generally have rifling in the barrel, but can be used to shoot shot. I know birdshot (ratshot) is available for .22 and .38 caliber pistols because that's what I used to keep in the first two chambers of all my revolvers. (If the ratshot doesn't get the perp's attention, the hollowpoint-crosscut tip jacketed bullet will cut him in half!--especially from the .357 Magnum Python.)

The guy is 78 years old, he's probably not as spry as he used to be.

 Perhaps this is Cheney's problem as well. He is getting up there in the years. When I was growing up I went to the cabin every year for deer and bear. It seemed every year that another one of the old guys would no longer go on the hunt. I understood that it was because they perhaps did not have the stamina, health, coordination or judgement that they once had. We had a name for that: dangerous. (as a side note: I used to feel sorry for them, but as I have grown older, I realize that it can't be all that bad to sit in the cabin drinking beer and playing poker all day!) 
 
 Hunting is not an especially dangerous activity, but it can be if the gun is in the wrong hands. As well, bird hunting across a field (what we call brush popping at home) can be more dangerous than sitting in a tree stand, as shots are often taken low to the ground and quickly. When I worked as medic in a rural area I saw people hit with shotgun blasts numerous times. Rarely is it ever life threatening.

daewoo

The site only confirms my statement if it takes one hand to fire it is a gun if it takes two hands it is a rifle.

 
 No, it doesn't, which is why there is a seperate category for "shotgun"
 
 What makes a "rifle" a "rifle" is the "rifling". From dictionary.com
 
 
ri·fle1 ( P ) Pronunciation Key (rfl)
 n. 
 
 A firearm with a rifled bore, designed to be fired from the shoulder. 
 An artillery piece or naval gun with such spiral grooves. 
 rifles Troops armed with rifles. 

 
 
shot·gun ( P ) Pronunciation Key (shtgn)
 n. 
 A smoothbore gun that fires shot over short ranges. Also called scattergun

 
 
 
 Rifles were so named because they were originally the only weapons with rifled barrels, and the term "rifle" distinguished them from a "musket", which had no "rifling".
 
 Pistols did not generally have rifled barrels until later for 2 reasons. The first is that they were not generally considered accurate enough to mess with rifling the barrel. This was due in large part to the amount of powder required for propulsion and the length of the pistols barrel. The powder and ball took up so much of the barrel that the remaining barrel length was not enough to stabilize the round.
 
 Once multiple fire guns became more popular (revolvers), they were generally built with longer barrels, which greatly aided accuracy. It was not until revolvers came on the scene though that you saw a lot of rifled pistol barrels. They certainly existed, but were not common and were a pretty expensive option.
 
 It could be argued that a shotgun with a rifled barrel is a rifle. There is a specific exemtion under current law for this requiring that for something to be considered a "rifle" it must utilize metallic cartriges.
 
 
Modern cannons usually have rifling. Modern pistols have rifling but are not considered rifles. I don't know how long the barrel (or stock) has to be before a pistol becomes a rifle, but I have seen pistols with extremely long barrels...one that had been fitted with a shoulder stock and forestock (still had the pistol grip and the revolving chamber) so I suppose there's a point at which the name would change.

 
 I would imagine barrel length, etc.. would be a matter of semantics. The buttstock is a matter of law, though. If it has a buttstock, it is legally a rifle and thus must have a 16" or longer barrel. If the weapon in quesiton has EVER had a buttstock, it is a rifle regardless of whether the buttstock is still attached. If it has PROVISIONS to attach a buttstock, it is a rifle.
 
 There are a couple of companies out there building AK based pistols. In order to do this, they have to use a new reciever (because in teh eyes of the law the reciever is the firearm) and fill the rear trunnion so the provisions for a buttstock are gone.

 IMO a 28 gauge is kind of a funny choice for a quail gun. Around here, most shoot 20 gauge or 12 guage. Whether you blow the bird to smithereens or not is a function of pellet size, choke, and range. A 12 guage firing 7 1/2 shot through a modified choke at 20 yards will kill your quail without severe damage. A .410 with a full choke and firing #6 shot will pulverize the bird at that range.

Everything that I hunt with a shotgun is with my Ithaca Model 37 20ga. As several have pointed out, it is not so much the shotgun, but the shell fired from the shotgun that really matters. I found this 20ga. to be useful for everything from rabbit to grouse, pheasant, and have even taken a deer with a slug. This is a good all around shotgun, but the proper shells are the key.

simone

Both shotguns and rifles require two hands to use, one to steady the barrel in the right direction, the other to hold the stock and to trigger the weapon. One is obliged to use one eye to sight the weapon, the new weaponry have little scopes to aid one in sighting and aiming, older weaponry had a little knob very close to one's eye that was lined up with a little slot further down the barrel.
 
 Automatic weaponry with huge armories of bullets and rapid-fire capacity--I don't know if those sorts of weapons are designed to be held with a single hand--I am sure that weapon-rabid individuals would truly like to have two weapons of this sort, one for each hand, inasmuch if you missed the first shot you would have so many bullets left to fire off rapidly that you would surely spatter your prey with at least some of those unless you were totally blind.
 
 Shotguns are designed for shortrange scattering of missiles, I guess primarily designed for wild fowl which are apt to move rapidly so that at least some of the scattered pellets would wing some of the creature.
 
 Rifles have one single lethal bullet per trigger pull and are used for larger game, I suppose that if one is attempting to gun down a buffalo or a rhino or possibly an elephant, one must have a larger calibre weapon with bullets designed to have a wider splattering effect.
 
 I understand that some bullets are designed to be quite nasty with they make contact with a soft body and the underlying bone--they flatten out and chop huge holes through the body of the prey, human or animal.

 Automatic weaponry with huge armories of bullets are not intended to be held in the hand. They are intended to be mounted. The only way you get "huge armories of bullets" is if they are belt fed.
 
 
 
I understand that some bullets are designed to be quite nasty with they make contact with a soft body and the underlying bone--they flatten out and chop huge holes through the body of the prey, human or animal.

 
 Shooting something is not synonomous with petting it. You shoot something because you want to make it dead. As such, huge holes through the body of the prey is a desirable result.

jim's trucking

What is the big deal about this? Simply because he is the vice president he has to notify the American public as soon as something like this happens? In his place I would have left all decisions about releasing information to the family of Whittington, out of respect for the family. I personally could care less what the vice president did. It was an accident, albeit a careless accident.
 
 But yes, one of the cardinal rules of shooting any firearm is to know your target and what is beyond your target. No excuses.
For the most part, I agree.
 
 However, anyone who has done some serious quail hunting (or any fast-moving target hunting) knows that the background is least considered when tracking and leading the bird (or rabbit) with the gun barrel. Sometimes, the reaction time between when you decide to fire and when you actually fire allows your barrel to move into a background that you have not fully studied, especially with low flying birds.
 
 It's greatly different from scoping in on a stationary deer, wild turkey or mountain goat. The hunter has sufficient time to examine the area around the target and determine that no other hunters are in the line of fire. Not so with hunting small game birds. One hardly ever steadies the gun prior to triggering. It's a moving target.
 
 In group hunts, people need to be aware of where everyone else is. I fault the shooter and the shootee in this regard. The shootee has already admitted he should have announced his position. The shooter has already taken full responsibility. They both erred.
 
 On the other hand, those who have never been hunting, despise guns and know nothing of how things work in the field will likely conjure up a picture of Cheney taking dead aim on a man in orange hunting gear and grinning demonically as his deliberately blows his friend away. This is NOT what happened.
jyoshu

Personally, I think it's silly that Democrats and the media are trying to play this up as some secrecy scandal. It seems to me there are much more pertinent issues over which to bring the secrecy accusation. Furthermore, it's not like the media didn't find out or wasn't alerted. The media isn't obligated to receive the info any certain way--there's nothing wrong with the way the information was released.
 
 Democrats have really been increasing the smear campaign lately, and this is only a part of that.

It is a big deal in deed. Using powers for not taking responsibility for his own actions. And to go one step further if it was a regular guy that was involved in a shooting like that. There would and might have been charges brought because of negligence.

 First off, it is pure speculation on your part to suggest that a "regular guy" would have been charged with a crime. I have known personally of several hunting accidents, and in none of the cases was anyone charged with a crime. 
 
 And Cheney has taken responsibility for his actions. He accepts full responsibility for the shooting. I am not aware of any law or statute requiring that if the vice president shoots someone that he is required to personally notify the media within a certain amount of time...are you?
snakespit

For the most part, I agree.
 
 However, anyone who has done some serious quail hunting (or any fast-moving target hunting) knows that the background is least considered when tracking and leading the bird (or rabbit) with the gun barrel. Sometimes, the reaction time between when you decide to fire and when you actually fire allows your barrel to move into a background that you have not fully studied, especially with low flying birds.
 
 It's greatly different from scoping in on a stationary deer, wild turkey or mountain goat. The hunter has sufficient time to examine the area around the target and determine that no other hunters are in the line of fire. Not so with hunting small game birds. One hardly ever steadies the gun prior to triggering. It's a moving target.
 
 In group hunts, people need to be aware of where everyone else is. I fault the shooter and the shootee in this regard. The shootee has already admitted he should have announced his position. The shooter has already taken full responsibility. They both erred.
 
 On the other hand, those who have never been hunting, despise guns and know nothing of how things work in the field will likely conjure up a picture of Cheney taking dead aim on a man in orange hunting gear and grinning demonically as his deliberately blows his friend away. This is NOT what happened.

 I have done a good bit of bird hunting, mostly grouse, but quail and pheasant as well. It is true that when shooting you are often after a moving target, and not "focused" on the background as you would be when still hunting. However, it is the responsibility of the hunters to be aware of their surroundings, and their positions relative to the other hunters. It is what we call in the aviation business situational awareness. If I don't know where Bob is, I am going to find out where he is regardless of how many birds fly out in front of me...before I shoot my gun.

 And Cheney has taken responsibility for his actions. He accepts full responsibility for the shooting. I am not aware of any law or statute requiring that if the vice president shoots someone that he is required to personally notify the media within a certain amount of time...are you?

He followed up with the hospital the same day on Whittingtons condition, and appears to be in close contact with him since the incident. 
 
 And sorry to burst your ego-bubble, but I don't think I heard Cheney ask for sympathy from the American public. He made a mistake, one that happens every now and then in hunting. Yes, it was a lack of caution and good judgement in this situation that led to the mistake, but that does not mean that Cheney is a reckless or dangerous person that should never be allowed to go hunting again. We all make mistakes and have accidents now and then.

 I owuld imagine they view it as both parties fault (Cheny and Whittington anyway). Both violated important, well understood, safety rules for hunting. 
 
 I have been thinkign about this a lot lately, mostly because I am an avid hunter and there are lessons to be learned here. I think that for the most part, the fault here lies with Whittington. While it is true that you theoretically should never fire unless you know for sure what is behind your target, As others have pointed out, in brush hunting this is not realistic. You know the lay of the land, and where your hunting buddies are. If domebody else wonders into the field, especially in somebodies field fo fire, they run the risk of being accidentally shot. 
 
 Whittington should have approached the group from the rear, and announced his approach the minute he was in range to do so (and if you are in range of a 28 gauge, you are in range to announce your approach). He withdrew from the hunting party and returned to the vehicle to rest. There was no way that Cheney, or anybody else in the field, would have known that he decide to return to the group. 
 
 We hunt birds here (kansas, it is kind of a big deal) and a lot of the best bird country is CRP, which often grows higher than your head. You always take shots where you cannot be 100% sure what is behind the target. I hunt fairly often with my wifes grandfather. His is 90, and not real spry. He routinely drops us at one end of the field then drives around to the other end to block. If he abandonded his post at the other end of the field and wandered in to find the rest of us, there is a good chance he might end up getting shot. Luckily he is smart enough (and considerate enough) not to do that kind of thing. If he did, I probably would not hunt with him anymore. The last thing I need on my conscience is the death of my wifes grandfather.
 
 This is a nothign deal. It was a mutual mistake made among friends.
sglaine

This is a nothign deal. It was a mutual mistake made among friends.

 
 
 And yes and those braindeads can rejoice..emoticon_xhoho Still in the real world you don't pull the trigger unless you know for sure what your shooting at. And that is common sence that was not used.
 
 And they teach that in Hunters safety class.
Mach

My first reaction, and most of my subsquent thought, is that yes, it's a mistake among friends, it's not really a big deal.
 
 Of course, I know some remarkable individuals that take everything they do very seriously, and to make such a potentially fatal blunder (on both parts...choosing to hunt in a low visibility error is still a choice), is not necessarily something we want to see our "leaders" doing. Are they this careless with our armed forces? (!)
 
 Another part of what I've heard, that sounds somewhat reasonable (although most conspiracy theories do), is that:
 
 1. It was out of the norm not to announce this immediately.
 2. The secret service turned away an officer investigating the incident and remarked they would discuss it the following day (time to let that blood alcohol level drop and get their stories synch'd up).
 3. There was a lot of confusion among witnesses and Cheney's remarks with regards to whether there was alcohol at lunch, how much was consumed, by who, and when...all relevant to many injury accidents (car, boating, etc.).
 
 Putting all three facts together looks suspicious, and when it's an elected executive of such enormous power (Cheney is like president-lite), it's perhaps worth a look. All this air time? Most news media is about entertainment, not fair, balanced, or otherwise facts-only information to better society. If we cared about what the news media did with their air time, we'd complain 90% of the time, not just about this. (I complain 90% of the time, so I watch news hour and listen to NPR)
 
 -Mach
billsco
